review.title: A Semantic Similarity Measure for Expressive Description Logics
review.abstract: A totally semantic measure is presented which is able to calculate a similarity value between concept descriptions and also between concept description and individual or between individuals expressed in an expressive description logic. It is applicable on symbolic descriptions although it uses a numeric approach for the calculus. Considering that Description Logics stand as the theoretic framework for the ontological knowledge representation and reasoning, the proposed measure can be effectively used for agglomerative and divisional clustering task applied to the semantic web domain.

sections.heading: 4 The Similarity Measure
sections.text: In this section, we present a measure of similarity that is capable of assessing the similarity between instances or between instance and concept, or even between concepts expressed in the logic of description and in particular in ALC logic. We call such elements generic objects. Then, we will formalize the measure for the different types of objects. The measure presented uses the basic set theory, which is based mainly on the commonality between objects. In particular, the basic criterion for this measure is: the similarity value between objects is not only the result of the common characteristics, but also the result of the different characteristics. This criterion is consistent with an information theory definition of similarity [25].

sections.heading: 5 Discussion
sections.text: First of all, it is important to point out that, unlike previously proposed similarity measures (see section 2), this measure is completely semantic. In fact, it uses only semantic conclusions such as instance verification (to solve the recall problem [1], which amounts to calculating the extension of a concept by an A-box); it does not use the syntactical structure of the concept description, so it is independent of the granularity level of the descriptions. This fact reflects the intrinsic complexity of expressive DL languages such as ALC, for which a structural approach to argumentation is simply ineffective (submission is calculated using tablets rather than a structural algorithm). Therefore, the definition of s uses quantity thetics and semantic services so that it makes use of the numerical approach despite its application on a symbolic DL representation.

sections.heading: 5.2 Complexity Issues
sections.text: In order to assess the complexity of s, the three different cases of the applicability of the measure are discussed separately, all of which depend on the complexity of the instance examining conclusions for the adopted DL language, hereinafter referred to as C (IC). Similarity between the concepts: s is a numerical measure, all calculations require constant complexity; it states that: C (s) = 3 · C (IC), because the instance examination is repeated three times: for the concept descriptions C, D and I. Similarity between an individual and a concept: In this case, in addition to the instance verification operations required in the previous case, the MSC approximation of the considered individual must be calculated. Consequently, the complexity of the MSC approximation referred to as C (MSC) depends, in addition to the MSC approximation, on the fact that: C (s) = C (MSC) = C (MSC) + 3 · C (previous similarity between the MSC approximation is analogous to the MSC: this is the difference between the two individuals).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: We have introduced a new similarity measure, which is primarily intended to calculate a similarity value between concept descriptions, but, as already shown, could also be used to assess the similarity between individuals and between a concept description and an individual. As already proposed, such a measure could be applied to many tasks, namely clustering and retrieval on DL knowledge bases. This measurement could be improved in the case of non-overlapping concepts. In particular, we will try to assess similarities in different cases using an idea of distance between concepts, which is closely related to the weakness of the presented semantic similarity measure in cases involving individuals. In particular, we are looking at our research on the coordination of a semantic operator to generalize the approximated MSC value. In this way, we could overcome the real problem, because the concept would be less specific than MSC and would instantiate more individuals than the one selected to calculate the similarity value.
